item.title: Do cheap GPS trackers work? A review of the GF-07, GF-09 and GF-22.
item.description: I wanted to explore how I might be able to track my bike easily. In this article, I laid out what I’d like the trackers to do, and my results from testing 3 cheap widely available trackers: the GF-07, GF-09, and GF-22.
item.author: (Adam Jones (domdomegg))

item.title: Unwind considered harmful? · baby steps
item.description: I’ve been thinking a wild thought lately: we should deprecate panic=unwind. Most production users I know either already run with panic=abort or use unwinding in a very limited fashion, basically just to run to cleanup, not to truly recover. Removing unwinding from most case meanwhile has a number of benefits, allowing us to extend the type system in interesting and potentially very impactful ways. It also removes a common source of subtle bugs. Note that I am not saying we should remove unwinding entirely: that’s not an option, both because of stability and because of Rust’s mission to “deeply integrate” with all kinds of languages and systems.

item.title: The Missing Piece: Lucidity
item.description: Lucidity, or clarity of thought, is vital in problem-solving. As a Senior Developer, I learned its importance the hard way during a project where my tunnel vision caused delays. My recent experience building this website with AI also highlighted AI's limitations in achieving true clarity. Despite these challenges, lucidity remains crucial, and while AI can assist, human expertise is indispensable.

item.title: Two years as an independent technologist · Applied Cartography
item.description: This week marks two full years since I left Stripe and started what in retrospect is a new (and likely) final phase of my career as an independent technologist. I didn’t quite know what that would entail at the time: it turned out to be a combination of founder (my work at Buttondown) and managing partner (my work at Third South).

item.title: vu128: Efficient variable-length integers
item.description: The basic goal of a variable-length integer encoding is to allow small numbers to be encoded in fewer bytes than larger numbers. Among other uses, they're popular for TLV formats such as Protocol Buffers, which contain lots of small numbers (tags) and have a design goal of space efficiency. The two encodings with near-universal adoption are VLQ and LEB128, which are the big- and little-endian dialects of an encoding originally developed in the early 1980s[0].
item.author: (John Millikin)
